title: How do I know if my back taxes were discharged in my Chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: I filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy and have gone to my hearing. I haven't gotten a discharge. I had back taxes from 2003 included in the bankruptcy. I filed my 2003 tax return in 2004. My lawyer told me that if the taxes weren't reassessed within 240 days prior to filing and if there was no fraud, then those taxes would go away. How do I know if the taxes were reassessed and how will I know if the taxes were discharged? Also, the IRS put a lien against my property. Can that be taken off by the filing of the chapter 7?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Tax lien,Debt,Lien,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Property tax liens,Real estate,Fraud,Tax return,Tax law
answers:
Contact the IRS Insolvency Unit, which handles debtors in bankruptcy. The IRS can tell you their position on your old taxes in light of your bankruptcy. Phone numbers can be found here: http://morganking.com/TaxJustice/Articles/NationalInsolvencyDirectory.pdf

Bankruptcy does not automatically affect liens. Removing liens requires a seperate action that is in addition to the bankruptcy filing, usually with additional cost. Whether a lien can be removed will depend on the equity and exemption applied. You should discuss this with your bankruptcy attorney, who will have a better idea based on your petition.

The way to find out about the dates of any assessments, etc. is to obtain a transcript from the taxing agency (also called a "record of account"). The taxes are either dischargeable, or they're not. If after your bankruptcy case is over and discharge entered the taxing agencies do not "believe" the taxes were discharged, and you have evidence to the contrary, then you will need to reopen the case and file a complaint to determine the dischargeability of the debt with the bankruptcy court.

As other posts pointed out, this is completely separate from any liens the IRS or FTB has against property on the date your case was filed. Any such liens will remain against the property you owned on the date your case is filed. Depending on the amounts involved, you may or may not be able to get the taxing agencies to abate the tax and release the liens after your bankruptcy case is closed.

Mark J. Markus, Attorney at Law
http://www.bklaw.com/

The tax lien will not be discharged by your bankruptcy. It is a debt that is secured by any & every thing you own, real estate, cars, furniture, money in the bank!

It is a little too soon to be asking the IRS for info on the amount of your tax debt because you haven't received your bankruptcy discharge yet. Be patient...the IRS won't forget about you.

Sorry I can't give you a better answer!

Your attorney has given you correct advice and you must continue to communicate with your own attorney about the specific circumstances of your case. There are four conditions under the bankruptcy law, all four of which must be met, in order for IRS taxes to be subject to discharge. You need to take all documents you have with regard to your taxes to your attorney, who can give you specific counsel regarding application of the bankruptcy law to your circumstances.
